author: davee123
title: An interesting experiment
review:
General Information

This set was released as a "custom" mosaic, where buyers could upload a picture to LEGO's website, which would then be rasterized into a custom mosaic (you could make minor alterations within the editor, or even "draw" a custom design yourself without a base image).  Alternatively, two "standard" images were available-- one of a cat's face, and one of a LEGO T-Rex.

The image is a 44x44 pixel graphic consisting of 4 colors: white, "very light gray", light gray, dark gray, and black.  The image was rendered using a variant of a program written by LEGO enthusiast Eric Harshbarger, modified for LEGO's website.

Parts

The contents of the set were made up of a fixed set of pieces for the mosaic frame and backing, and small bags of 1x1 plates, each containing 90 of a single color.  Depending on your image, you could get between 22 and 26 total bags of 1x1s.  The frame had an option to be built with a small hole to hang it up on a wall.

At the time, both very light gray and dark gray were difficult to come by, and this set was a welcome source of both colors.  Otherwise, the fact that it included a 48x48 baseplate ($11 at the time) meant that the remaining 2300 (or so) pieces were only about $20-- considered a very good deal at the time.  (Interestingly, the piece count was listed as 1,993 pieces even though the minimum amount that came with the set was 2,036)

The build

As you might expect, the process of building the mosaic is tedious (recommended age range by LEGO was 10+), as there were nearly 2000 pieces to add individually, and mistakes are easy to make.

The completed model

The resulting mosaic is nice, although probably not sophisticated enough to be a very nice showpiece, since the pixel level isn't sufficient for capturing much detail.  It would have been aided greatly by a very wide color palette, or an option to make larger mosaics (neither of which were easy for LEGO to do at the time)

Overall opinion

The set remains an interesting experiment on LEGO's behalf that wasn't quite neat enough to be a winner, but marked perhaps the first time that LEGO sets could actually be highly customized for purchase.
